_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Rust-Oleum Corporation (Rust-Oleum) Kenosha is subject to the United States Environmental

Protection Agency's (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) for Accidental Chemical Release

(40 CFR 68) because it stores a mixture of n-Propane (CAS 74-98-6) and Isobutane (CAS 106-97-

8), each in excess of 10,000 pounds, within aerosol paint cans as propellant.  A total of

approximately 2.3 million pounds of propellant may be stored, at any one time, in the DC. Finished

goods are transferred to the DC for interim storage prior to shipment to retail stores.

WORST-CASE SCENARIO

For the Worst-Case Scenario, the aerosol can contents are considered non-toxic, but flammable and

a highly explosive gas. The mixture within each aerosol can is propellant (the n-Propane and

Isobutane), flammable liquid solvents and paint solids, with each can containing approximately 16-oz

of this flammable mixture. As the propellant is the more flammable/explosive component in the

aerosol can, the entire 16-oz is assumed all propellant in a 65/35 weight % split n-Propane to

Isobutane. The individual aerosol cans are stored in cardboard cases, 6 per case. 274 cases are

stored on a single pallet. The pallets are then stacked no more than 2 high in multiple rows within

the DC. A single pallet of aerosol cans was considered a single vessel, with the instantaneous

release of the mixture in all the aerosol cans on the pallet as a Worst-Case Scenario.

The Offsite Consequence distance to an over pressure of 1 psi was determined using equation C-2

provided in Appendix C of the OCAG guidance document; dated April 15, 1999. No administrative

controls or passive mitigation systems were considered in this scenario. The heat of combustion

values were obtained from Exhibit C-1 of Appendix C of the OCAG guidance document. The

following values were used in the calculations: 45,719 kJ/kg for Isobutane and 46,333 kJ/kg for n-

Propane.

Because the site qualifies for the RMP Program 1 requirements,

no alternative release scenario was

required to be assessed.

OFF-SITE IMPACT

The endpoint distance from the worst-case release scenario, 0.095 miles (501 feet), does not extend

beyond the property line. Therefore, no public or environmental

receptors are impacted.

ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of the covered flammable substances at the Kenosha

DC facility in the last 5 years that have resulted in death, injury or significant property damage onsite;

or off-site death, injury, property damage, evacuation, sheltering in place, or environmental

damage.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

Although a formal, documented prevention program is not required by the RMP rule for Program 1

processes, a number of design and operational controls are in place to decrease the severity or

prevent the occurrence of a fire or explosion. The most significant controls are described below:

1. The warehouse is designed as an aerosol warehouse in accordance with the National Fire

Protection Association (NFPA) Manufacture and Storage of Aerosol

Products code (NFPA 30B).

2. Aerosol storage is limited to a maximum height of 15 feet, i.e., 2 pallets.

3. The pallets of aerosol cans are stored separate from other flammable liquids and separated by

a 2 hour minimum rated fire wall.

4. A newly installed fire system including foam delivery system has been installed in the facility. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

An Emergency Action Plan is maintained at the facility and reviewed annually to

update and/or make recommended improvements to site safety.
